g.text: (O–Hvibrations). The broad IR band from720 cm
a appears to be due to the overlapping of the basil EOabsorption bands in the 600–800 cm
(O–H vibrations). The broad IR band from 720 cm
in Figure 3a appears to be due to the overlapping of the basil EO absorption bands in the 600–800
FTIR spectra of the HAp sample.
Furthermore, the normalized absorption IR spectra of basil EO and HAp-B presented in Figure 3
could provide a quantitative evaluation of the basil EO absorption into the HAp sample. By
comparing the IR spectrum of HAp (Figure 2) with the IR spectrum of HAp-B (Figure 3b),
wavenumber differences can be noticed, especially in the 1400–4000 cm
in the IR spectrum of the HAp-B sample, the bands specific to basil EO were not clearly highlighted,
although there are many IR-specific bands of basil EO in the 400–1400 cm
case concerning the IR bands at 2852, 2925, and 2964 cm
. In the spectrum of the HAp-B sample, only
the basil EO IR absorption bands of 1640 and 3310 cm
, attributed to O-H vibrations, were visible
(Figure 2). These bands were partially overlaid with the 1645 and 3338 cm
FTIR spectra of the HAp sample.
(O–H vibrations). The broad IR band from 720 cm
in Figure 3a appears to be due to the overlapping of the basil EO absorption bands in the 600–800
FTIR spectra of the HAp sample.
Furthermore, the normalized absorption IR spectra of basil EO and HAp-B presented in Figure 3
could provide a quantitative evaluation of the basil EO absorption into the HAp sample. By

although there are many IR-specific bands of basil EO in the 400–1400 cm

. In the spectrum of the HAp-B sample, only
the basil EO IR absorption bands of 1640 and 3310 cm
, attributed to O-H vibrations, were visible
